hobby.message: Urban exploration or just avoiding work?
Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Cameras? Not where I go.
I spend time exploring service tunnels, keeps me busy.
Some places got crowded lately, new faces poking around.
Doesn't matter, I stay out of sight.
No cameras that I saw. I usually slip through quiet spots.
I like mapping old tunnels—call it urban exploration.
Been trickier since the whole lottery mess. More folks down there now.
Hard to find a spot that's still private.
Still, I manage my routes.
No cameras—at least not where I spend my evenings.
Urban exploration, mostly tunnels and data vaults.
Keeps me sane when the city’s losing its grip.
Last week, I ran into some 'reassigned' volunteers chasing pipes.
Everybody wants a shortcut to resources after the lottery mess.
Makes the hobby a bit more crowded than I like.
Cameras haven’t caught up to my hideouts yet. I do urban exploration—service corridors, sealed data centers.
It started as a side project, now it’s my main escape.
Lately, I’ve seen more lost faces underground—folks dumped there by the lottery job reroutes.
Had to steer a few away from the live lines.
This mutual aid push is turning the tunnels into a parade route.
Strange times for a hobbyist like me.
Kind of miss the quiet, not gonna lie.
No, thankfully—still safer underground than above. I’ve spent years exploring utility tunnels—call it my personal tour of Stenograd's nervous system.
Started back when I left state work, needed space and a bit of risk.
These days I chart dead drops, follow forgotten wiring, stash a flask near old junctions.
Since the whole BCI breakdown and the loyalty lottery, the tunnels are full of newbies and wannabe 'volunteers.'
Funny—used to be just me, the dark, and broken valves.
Now, half the city's out looking for shortcuts, or claiming they built the place.
Saw someone foul up a coolant line last night—almost lost power on my floor.
Gotta be careful where I fix things now, make sure no one’s watching.
Guess it’s my own private rebellion—keep the city running, quietly undermine the Council’s games.
hobby_answer: Yeah, urban exploring. Still at it.
Not as easy lately with all the 'aid volunteers' wandering places they shouldn't.
Tunnel entrances starting to get watched, too.
Lottery nonsense stirred folks up more than usual.
Hard to move around unnoticed. That’s all.
Still poking around the hidden parts of the city. Can't help myself.
Whole place feels busier since the system glitched—too many new faces in the tunnels.
People think they're fixing things, mostly just get lost or leak something crucial.
Between revamped BCI and this rigged lottery, hobby got a little riskier.
I don't record my routes anymore—too many eyes, digital and otherwise.
Trying to stay a step ahead of the crowd.
Yeah, still mixing exploring with a sip or two of my own concoction.
Except now the utility tunnels are full of green volunteers, thanks to those BCI labor ‘lotteries’.
Found three stuck trying to reboot a coolant valve last night—almost caused a blackout.
Used to enjoy peace down there, now every corridor echoes with amateur footsteps.
Most never used to notice access hatches until all this unrest.
I’ll admit, the challenge is new. Not sure I like it.
Might just have to change up my routes.
You know me—liquor in one hand, lamp in the other, urban spelunking.
Tunnels used to be my sanctuary after hours. Silent, steady, mostly empty.
Now? Half the city’s been reassigned to 'volunteer' repairs since the system went sideways.
Ran into a group arguing over an old schematic—never seen more lost experts in my life.
Lottery outcomes are a joke, honestly. High-score folks trying to fix valves they've never touched.
Last week someone botched a relay—almost cost us cold storage.
Sometimes I patch it up quietly, sometimes I let it ride—teaches ‘em.
Still, I keep my flask close and my secrets closer.
Urban exploring, same as always—just more crowded these days, thanks to Council lottery chaos.
Started back when silence was a given and only the rats kept me company.
BCI collapse sent a flood of amateurs into places I used to know by heart.
Saw a Harmonist councilman’s son trying to repair a vapor line—holding a map upside down.
People don’t get the city’s pulse, not really. You feel it best alone, off the record.
After the rigged lottery leak, everybody’s nervous and jumpy. More patrols, more suspicion.
Had to reroute twice last night. Spotters on the access stairs who wouldn’t have dared six months ago.
Still worth it for the peace, when I get it. But I miss the old days.
Guess even hobbies have to adapt in Stenograd now.
